name: Non-equal Neighbours
statement: You are given an array of $$$n$$$ positive integers $$$a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$$$. Your task is to calculate the number of arrays of $$$n$$$ positive integers $$$b_1, b_2, \ldots, b_n$$$ such that: $$$1 \le b_i \le a_i$$$ for every $$$i$$$ ($$$1 \le i \le n$$$), and $$$b_i \neq b_{i+1}$$$ for every $$$i$$$ ($$$1 \le i \le n - 1$$$). The number of such arrays can be very large, so print it modulo $$$998\,244\,353$$$.
inputFormat: The first line contains a single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \le n \le 2 \cdot 10^5$$$) â€” the length of the array $$$a$$$. The second line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$$$ ($$$1 \le a_i \le 10^9$$$).
outputFormat: Print the answer modulo $$$998\,244\,353$$$ in a single line.
